summary: The document is a classified memorandum from the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) to the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB), addressing inquiries related to the John F. Kennedy assassination. It details the commercial cover program's ties to the publications industry, the extent of company participation in the 1960s, and the confidentiality agreements required of those involved. The memorandum also includes the secrecy agreements used by the CIA from 1955 to 1988 and its updated version, underscoring the confidential nature of the relationship between the U.S. Government and program participants.
key_findings: The commercial cover program had connections to both real businesses and contrived facilities within the publications industry.
During the 1960s, around 500 companies were part of the commercial cover program.
The CIA utilized a secrecy agreement from 1955 to 1988, which was later updated with an addendum in 1991.
The document stresses the confidentiality obligations of individuals and organizations involved with the U.S. Government, prohibiting unauthorized information disclosure.
